article_title: Child support upgrade is $73 million over initial cost, years away from being done
article_text:
Child support upgrade is $73 million over initial cost, years away from being done

Photo: Andy Jacobsohn / Dallas Morning News Campaigning, Greg Abbott frequently cites his office's work on the... AUSTIN — Republican gubernatorial hopeful Greg Abbott touts his success as attorney general in collecting billions of dollars in child support.

article_metadata.description: The documents detail problems with an antiquated child-support enforcement system that relies on paper case files, lacks real-time data, is difficult to navigate, requires “laborious” workarounds and has no centralized security infrastructure to manage user access.  Abbott's office says it's on the right path after making changes, which include giving lead contractor Accenture LLP a more independent role in driving the initiative along with contract increases totaling about $30 million.  The child-support program is a big part of the agency overseen by Abbott, and thus an important part of the résumé he is packing as he battles Democratic state Sen. Wendy Davis of Forth Worth for governor.  The Legislature allocated $594.8 million and 2,748 full-time positions for the current two-year budget period for child-support enforcement activities — more than half the agency's staffing and of its budget, in state and federal dollars combined.  Of the increase, Rolfe said $15 million is an “artificial” boost from adding salaries for agency employees who aren't new, but whose pay wasn't previously included.  The amount of information stored in the system is growing at a rate of about 20 percent a year “with no ability to archive data,” according to budget documents, and its navigation requires users “to go through a steep and long learning curve and often perform laborious manual workarounds to complete even routine tasks.”  The paper-based case file system reduces the efficiency of the agency and constrains its ability to share information across field offices, records show.  The February review also said the decision to use offshore developers at the India center “poses risks that are well documented in multiple case studies,” citing schedule and budget issues that arise from managing a global development team, quality concerns, instability and staff turnover.  The Associated Press has reported that Kenneth Wolfe, a spokesman for the federal Administration for Children and Families, said concerns identified in the periodic reviews have “continually been satisfactorily addressed.”  If you look at private sector you will find these issues, too, with big technology projects, said Sherri Greenberg, director of the Center for Politics and Governance at UT's Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs.
article_metadata.author.name: By Peggy Fikac, Austin Bureau
